It is a more serious form of house-trespass committed by entering through a passage not intended for entrance, or by unfastening a lock, etc., or by using criminal force, or by entering when a passage is open but quitting through a different means.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive - Element for S.453, 454)

title: Section 446 - House-breaking by night
content: This section defines 'House-Breaking by Night'. It is house-breaking committed after sunset and before sunrise.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive - Element for S.456, 457)

title: Section 447 - Punishment for criminal trespass
content: This section provides the punishment for the general offence of criminal trespass, as defined in S.441.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine up to Rs. 500, or both

title: Section 448 - Punishment for house-trespass
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence of house-trespass, as defined in S.442.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine up to Rs. 1000, or both

title: Section 449 - House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death
content: This section punishes house-trespass committed with the intention of committing an offence that is punishable with death.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 450 - House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment for life
content: This section punishes house-trespass committed with the intention of committing an offence that is punishable with imprisonment for life.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 451 - House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: This section punishes house-trespass committed with the intention of committing an offence punishable with imprisonment.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, and fine (If offence is theft, punishment is under S.454)

title: Section 452 - House-trespass after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint
content: This section punishes house-trespass committed after making preparation for causing hurt, assault, or wrongful restraint to any person.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 453 - Punishment for lurking house-trespass
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence of lurking house-trespass, as defined in S.443.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, and fine

title: Section 454 - Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: This section punishes lurking house-trespass or house-breaking committed with the intention of committing an offence punishable with imprisonment.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, and fine (If offence is theft, punishment is under S.457, 458)

title: Section 455 - Lurking house-trespass or house-breaking after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint
content: This section punishes lurking house-trespass or house-breaking committed after making preparation for causing hurt, assault, or wrongful restraint.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 456 - Punishment for lurking house-trespass by night
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence of lurking house-trespass by night, as defined in S.444.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, and fine

title: Section 457 - Lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night in order to commit offence punishable with imprisonment
content: This section punishes lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night committed with the intention of committing an offence punishable with imprisonment.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 5 years, and fine

title: Section 458 - Lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night after preparation for hurt, assault or wrongful restraint
content: This section punishes lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night committed after making preparation for causing hurt, assault, or wrongful restraint.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 14 years, and fine

title: Section 459 - Grievous hurt caused whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking
content: This section punishes causing grievous hurt to any person whilst committing lurking house-trespass or house-breaking.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 460 - All persons jointly concerned in lurking house-trespass or house-breaking by night punishable where death or grievous hurt caused by one of them
content: If multiple persons commit lurking house-trespass by night or house-breaking by night, and one of them causes death or grievous hurt, all are guilty of the offence described in this section.. Punishment: Death, or Imprisonment for life, or rigorous imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 461 - Dishonestly breaking open receptacle containing property
content: This section punishes dishonestly breaking open any closed receptacle (e.g., container, box, room) which contains or is believed to contain property.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 462 - Punishment for same offence when committed by person entrusted with custody
content: This section provides enhanced punishment for the offence described in S.461 if it is committed by a person who was entrusted with the custody of the receptacle.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, and fine

title: Section 463 - Forgery
content: This section defines the offence of 'Forgery'. It involves making a false document or electronic record (or part of one) with the intent to cause damage or injury, to support a claim or title, or to cause any person to part with property or enter into an express or implied contract.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive - Element for S.465)

title: Section 464 - Making a false document
content: This section defines what constitutes 'Making a false document' for the purpose of forgery. It includes signing a document in the name of another person without their authority, or altering a document without authority in a material way.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive)

title: Section 465 - Punishment for forgery
content: This section provides the punishment for the general offence of forgery, as defined in S.463.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 466 - Forgery of record of Court or of public register, etc.
content: This section provides enhanced punishment for forgery of a document which is a record of a Court or a public register, or a state-issued document like a birth certificate.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 467 - Forgery of valuable security, will, etc.
content: This section provides enhanced punishment for forgery of a document which is a valuable security (e.g., promissory note), a will, or an authority to adopt a son.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 468 - Forgery for purpose of cheating
content: This section punishes forgery committed for the purpose of cheating.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 469 - Forgery for purpose of harming reputation
content: This section punishes forgery committed for the purpose of harming the reputation of any person or knowing that it is likely to be used for that purpose.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, and fine

title: Section 470 - Forged document
content: This section defines a 'Forged Document' as a document that is forged within the meaning of S.463.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive)

title: Section 471 - Using as genuine a forged document
content: This section punishes fraudulently or dishonestly using as genuine any forged document, knowing it to be forged.. Punishment: Punishment as for forgery of such document

title: Section 472 - Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery
content: This section punishes making or counterfeiting any seal, plate, etc., or possessing such a counterfeit seal with the intention of committing forgery.. Punishment: Punishment as for forgery (S.467) i.e., up to life imprisonment, and fine

title: Section 473 - Making or possessing counterfeit seal, etc., with intent to commit forgery punishable under section 467
content: This section provides enhanced punishment for making or possessing a counterfeit seal, etc., with the intention of committing a forgery that would be punishable under S.467 (forgery of valuable security, will).. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 474 - Having possession of document described in section 466 or 467, knowing it to be forged and intending to use it as genuine
content: This section punishes having possession of a forged document (of the type described in S.466 or S.467), knowing it to be forged and intending to use it as genuine.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 475 - Counterfeiting device or mark used for authenticating documents described in section 467, or possessing counterfeit marked material
content: This section punishes counterfeing any device or mark used for authenticating documents described in S.467, or possessing paper or other material with such a counterfeit mark.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 476 - Counterfeiting signature, etc., of a person with intent to commit forgery
content: This section punishes counterfeiting any signature, handwriting, etc., of a person with the intention of committing forgery.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 477 - Fraudulent cancellation, destruction, etc., of will, authority to adopt, or valuable security
content: This section punishes fraudulently or dishonestly cancelling, destroying, or defacing a will, authority to adopt, or valuable security, or attempting to do so.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 477A - Falsification of accounts
content: This section punishes a clerk, officer, or servant who destroys, alters, or falsifies any account book or document belonging to their employer, with intent to defraud.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 478 - Trade Marks
content: [Repealed by the Trade Marks Act, 1999]. Punishment: nan

title: Section 479 - Property mark
content: This section defines a 'Property Mark'. It is a mark used to denote that movable property belongs to a particular person. It is different from a trademark, which denotes manufacture or quality.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive)

title: Section 480 - Using a false trade mark
content: [Repealed by the Trade Marks Act, 1999]. Punishment: nan

title: Section 481 - Using a false property mark
content: This section punishes using a false property mark with the intention of causing it to be believed that the goods belong to a person to whom they do not belong.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

title: Section 482 - Punishment for using a false property mark
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence described in S.481.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

title: Section 483 - Counterfeiting a property mark used by another
content: This section punishes counterfeiting any property mark used by another person.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 484 - Counterfeiting a mark used by a public servant
content: This section punishes counterfeiting any property mark or mark used by a public servant to denote that property meets a certain standard or has been inspected.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, and fine

title: Section 485 - Making or possession of any instrument for counterfeiting a property mark
content: This section punishes making or possessing any die, plate, or other instrument for the purpose of counterfeiting a property mark.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 486 - Selling goods marked with a counterfeit property mark
content: This section punishes selling, or exposing for sale, any goods with a counterfeit property mark, knowing that the mark is counterfeit.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

title: Section 487 - Making a false mark upon any receptacle containing goods
content: This section punishes making a false mark upon any case, package, or other receptacle containing goods, with intent to cause it to be believed that the contents are better or different than they are.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 488 - Punishment for making use of any such false mark
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence described in S.487.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 489 - Tampering with property mark with intent to cause injury
content: This section punishes removing, destroying, or defacing a property mark with the intention of causing injury to any person.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

title: Section 489A - Counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes
content: This section punishes counterfeiting, or performing any part of the process of counterfeiting, any currency-note or bank-note.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 489B - Using as genuine, forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes
content: This section punishes selling to, buying from, or using as genuine, any forged or counterfeit currency-note, knowing it to be forged or counterfeit.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 489C - Possession of forged or counterfeit currency-notes or bank-notes
content: This section punishes possessing any forged or counterfeit currency-note, knowing it to be forged or counterfeit, with the intention of using it as genuine.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 489D - Making or possessing instruments or materials for forging or counterfeiting currency-notes or bank-notes
content: This section punishes making or possessing any machinery, instrument, or material for the purpose of being used in forging or counterfeiting currency-notes.. Punishment: Imprisonment for life, or imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 489E - Making or using documents resembling currency-notes or bank-notes
content: This section punishes making, selling, or using any document that resembles a currency-note or bank-note so closely as to be mistaken for one, unless authorized by the RBI.. Punishment: Fine up to Rs. 100

title: Section 490 - Breach of contract of service during voyage or journey
content: [Repealed]. Punishment: nan

title: Section 491 - Breach of contract to attend on and supply wants of helpless person
content: This section punishes a person bound by a contract to attend on or supply the needs of a helpless person (e.g., due to youth, mental illness, sickness) if they fail to do so.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine up to Rs. 200, or both

title: Section 492 - Breach of contract to serve at distant place to which servant is conveyed at master's expense
content: [Repealed]. Punishment: nan

title: Section 493 - Cohabitation caused by a man deceitfully inducing a belief of lawful marriage
content: This section punishes a man who, by deceit, induces a woman to have sexual intercourse with him by making her believe that she is lawfully married to him.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 494 - Marrying again during lifetime of husband or wife
content: This section defines and punishes the offence of 'Bigamy'. It involves marrying again while having a husband or wife still living, unless the first marriage is void or has been dissolved.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 495 - Same offence with concealment of former marriage from person with whom subsequent marriage is contracted
content: This section provides enhanced punishment for bigamy if the offender concealed the fact of the former marriage from the person with whom the subsequent marriage is contracted.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 10 years, and fine

title: Section 496 - Marriage ceremony fraudulently gone through without lawful marriage
content: This section punishes a person who dishonestly or fraudulently goes through a marriage ceremony knowing that it is not a lawful marriage.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 7 years, and fine

title: Section 497 - Adultery
content: [This section was declared unconstitutional by the Supreme Court of India in 2018 (Joseph Shine vs. Union of India)]. Punishment: [Unconstitutional]

title: Section 498 - Enticing or taking away or detaining with criminal intent a married woman
content: This section punishes taking or enticing away a married woman, or detaining her, with the intention that she may have illicit intercourse with any person. It is intended to protect the rights of the husband.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 498A - Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty
content: This section punishes a husband or his relative who subjects a woman to cruelty. 'Cruelty' is defined as conduct that drives her to suicide or causes grave injury/danger to life/health, or harassment for dowry.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, and fine

title: Section 499 - Defamation
content: This section defines the offence of 'Defamation'. It involves making or publishing any imputation concerning a person, intending to harm their reputation, or knowing it is likely to harm their reputation. Exceptions include truth for public good and fair criticism.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive - Element for S.500)

title: Section 500 - Punishment for defamation
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence of defamation, as defined in S.499.. Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 501 - Printing or engraving matter known to be defamatory
content: This section punishes printing or engraving any defamatory matter, knowing it to be defamatory.. Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 502 - Sale of printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter
content: This section punishes selling or offering for sale any printed or engraved substance containing defamatory matter, knowing it to be defamatory.. Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 503 - Criminal intimidation
content: This section defines 'Criminal Intimidation'. It involves threatening another person with injury to their person, reputation, or property, or to someone they care about, with the intent to alarm them or make them do something they are not legally bound to do.. Punishment: N/A (Interpretive - Element for S.506)

title: Section 504 - Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace
content: This section punishes intentionally insulting a person with the knowledge that the insult is likely to provoke them to break the public peace or commit any other offence.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both

title: Section 505 - Statements conducing to public mischief
content: This section punishes making, publishing, or circulating any statement, rumor, or report that may cause fear/alarm to the public, incite any class to commit an offence against another, or promote enmity between classes.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both (If in place of worship, etc., up to 5 years)

title: Section 506 - Punishment for criminal intimidation
content: This section provides the punishment for the offence of criminal intimidation, as defined in S.503. If the threat is to cause death, grievous hurt, etc., the punishment is higher.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine, or both (If threat is to cause death/grievous hurt/etc., imprisonment up to 7 years, or fine, or both)

title: Section 507 - Criminal intimidation by an anonymous communication
content: This section provides enhanced punishment for criminal intimidation if the threat is delivered by an anonymous communication or after taking steps to conceal the identity or residence of the threatener.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 2 years, in addition to the punishment under S.506

title: Section 508 - Act caused by inducing person to believe that he will be rendered an object of the Divine displeasure
content: This section punishes voluntarily causing a person to do something by inducing a belief that they will become an object of divine displeasure if they do not. This often involves superstition or religious manipulation.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

title: Section 509 - Word, gesture or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman
content: This section punishes any word, sound, gesture, or act intended to insult the modesty of a woman, intruding upon her privacy. This is a broader provision than S.354.. Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both

title: Section 510 - Misconduct in public by a drunken person
content: This section punishes a person who, in a state of intoxication, appears in any public place or in any place which is a public nuisance, and misconducts themselves in a way that causes annoyance to others.. Punishment: Simple imprisonment up to 24 hours, or fine up to Rs. 10, or both

title: Section 511 - Punishment for attempting to commit offences punishable with imprisonment for life or other imprisonment
content: This section provides the general punishment for attempting to commit any offence for which no specific punishment for the attempt is provided elsewhere in the Code. The punishment is up to one-half of the longest term of imprisonment provided for the completed offence, or a fine, or both.. Punishment: Imprisonment up to one-half of the longest term provided for the offence, or fine, or both

title: Cognizable Offence
content: A serious crime where police can arrest without a warrant and start investigation immediately without court permission.. Example: Murder (S.302 IPC), Rape (S.376 IPC), Robbery (S.392 IPC) are cognizable offences where police can arrest immediately.

title: Non-Cognizable Offence
content: A less serious crime where police cannot arrest without warrant and need court permission to investigate.. Example: Simple hurt (S.323 IPC), Defamation (S.500 IPC), or public nuisance are non-cognizable offences requiring court order for investigation.

title: Bailable Offence
content: A crime where accused has right to be released on bail after arrest, either by police or court.. Example: Being member of unlawful assembly (S.143 IPC) or simple hurt (S.323 IPC) are bailable offences where bail is matter of right.

title: Non-Bailable Offence
content: A serious crime where getting bail is not automatic but depends on court's discretion based on case facts.. Example: Murder (S.302 IPC), Dowry death (S.304B IPC), Rape (S.376 IPC) are non-bailable offences where court decides bail.

title: First Information Report (FIR)
content: The first written complaint about a cognizable offence recorded by police, which starts criminal investigation.. Example: When theft occurs, victim's complaint recorded as FIR under S.379 IPC at police station initiates investigation.

title: Anticipatory Bail
content: Pre-arrest bail granted by court when person fears arrest, directing police to release them if arrested.. Example: Under S.438 CrPC, person fearing false accusation in cheating case (S.420 IPC) can get anticipatory bail before arrest.

title: Regular Bail
content: Bail granted to person already arrested and in custody, either by police station or court.. Example: Under S.437 CrPC, arrested person in theft case (S.379 IPC) can apply for regular bail in court.

title: Interim Bail
content: Temporary bail granted for short period pending final decision on regular or anticipatory bail application.. Example: Court may grant 7-day interim bail in assault case (S.352 IPC) while considering main bail application.

title: Default Bail
content: Automatic bail right when police fail to complete investigation and file chargesheet within stipulated time.. Example: Under S.167(2) CrPC, accused gets default bail if police don't file chargesheet within 90 days for serious offences.

title: Bail Bond
content: Legal document where accused and sureties promise court that accused will appear for trial when required.. Example: For bail in theft case, accused and two sureties sign Rs. 25,000 bond promising court attendance.

title: Surety
content: Person who guarantees to court that accused will comply with bail conditions and appear for trial.. Example: Father acts as surety for son accused in fight case, risking his own money if son misses court dates.

title: Personal Bond
content: Accused's own promise to court to appear for trial without needing sureties, based on personal credibility.. Example: In minor offences, court may release accused on personal bond of Rs. 10,000 without sureties.

title: Charge Sheet
content: Final police report after investigation containing evidence and charges against accused, filed in court.. Example: After completing theft investigation, police file chargesheet under S.379 IPC with evidence list.

title: Summons
content: Court order directing person to appear before it as accused or witness on specified date and time.. Example: Court issues summons to accused in cheque bounce case (S.138 NI Act) to appear for hearing.

title: Warrant
content: Court order authorizing police to arrest person and produce them before court.. Example: When accused avoids court appearances, magistrate issues arrest warrant under S.70 CrPC.

title: Non-Bailable Warrant
content: Court order for immediate arrest where bail cannot be granted by police and must be sought from court.. Example: In serious offences like murder, court issues non-bailable warrant requiring accused to be produced in custody.

title: Culpable Homicide
content: Causing death with intention to cause death or knowledge that act is likely to cause death.. Example: Pushing someone from height knowing it may cause death amounts to culpable homicide under S.299 IPC.

title: Murder
content: Culpable homicide committed with intention to cause death or bodily injury likely to cause death.. Example: Intentionally shooting someone in head amounts to murder under S.300 IPC punishable under S.302 IPC.

title: Dowry Death
content: Death of woman within 7 years of marriage caused by burns/bodily injury with dowry harassment evidence.. Example: Bride's death by poisoning with evidence of dowry demands falls under S.304B IPC.

title: Cheating
content: Dishonestly deceiving person to deliver property or consent to retaining property.. Example: Selling fake gold jewelry as real gold constitutes cheating under S.415 IPC punishable under S.420 IPC.

title: Theft
content: Dishonestly taking movable property out of person's possession without consent.. Example: Taking phone from someone's pocket without knowledge amounts to theft under S.378 IPC.

title: Robbery
content: Theft or extortion where offender causes or attempts to cause death/hurt/fear of instant hurt.. Example: Snatching chain while pushing victim constitutes robbery under S.390 IPC.

title: Dacoity
content: Robbery committed by five or more persons acting together.. Example: Five people jointly attacking and looting jewelry shop amounts to dacoity under S.391 IPC.

title: Criminal Breach of Trust
content: Dishonestly misappropriating property entrusted to oneself.. Example: Warehouse keeper selling stored goods instead of safeguarding them breaches trust under S.405 IPC.

title: Affidavit
content: Written statement confirmed by oath/affirmation before authorized officer, used as evidence.. Example: Witness files affidavit stating what they saw, sworn before notary public for court case.

title: Alibi
content: Defense claim that accused was elsewhere when crime occurred, making commission impossible.. Example: Accused proves he was in different city through hotel bills and CCTV footage when crime occurred.

title: Burden of Proof
content: Obligation to prove facts in dispute; generally on prosecution in criminal cases.. Example: Prosecution must prove accused's guilt beyond reasonable doubt in murder trial.

title: Beyond Reasonable Doubt
content: High standard of proof required for criminal conviction where no logical doubt remains.. Example: In rape case, DNA evidence and victim testimony together establish guilt beyond reasonable doubt.

title: Cross-Examination
content: Questioning of witness by opposite party to test truthfulness and accuracy of testimony.. Example: Defense lawyer questions prosecution witness about inconsistencies in theft incident description.

title: Examination-in-Chief
content: Initial questioning of witness by party who called them, to present their version of facts.. Example: Prosecutor questions victim about how robbery occurred and what was stolen.

title: Hostile Witness
content: Witness who testifies against party who called them or becomes uncooperative in court.. Example: Prosecution witness unexpectedly supports defense version despite earlier statements to police.

title: Circumstantial Evidence
content: Indirect evidence from which main fact can be inferred through logical reasoning.. Example: Accused's fingerprints on weapon and running from crime scene are circumstantial evidence of murder.

title: Direct Evidence
content: Evidence that directly proves fact without needing inference, like eyewitness testimony.. Example: Witness testifying 'I saw A stab B' provides direct evidence of assault.

title: Arrest
content: Taking person into legal custody, depriving them of liberty for investigation/trial.. Example: Police arrest theft suspect caught red-handed under S.41 CrPC.

title: Police Custody
content: Detention of accused in police lock-up for investigation purposes with court permission.. Example: Court grants 3 days police custody for interrogation in kidnapping case.

title: Judicial Custody
content: Detention of accused in jail under court orders during trial period.. Example: After police custody ends, accused sent to judicial custody till trial completion.

title: Remand
content: Court order sending accused back to custody (police or judicial) after production in court.. Example: Magistrate grants 2 days police remand for further investigation in robbery case.

title: Compoundable Offence
content: Crime where complainant can compromise with accused and withdraw case with court permission.. Example: Hurt cases (S.324 IPC) are compoundable where parties can settle with court approval.

title: Non-Compoundable Offence
content: Serious crime where compromise not allowed and state must prosecute case.. Example: Murder (S.302 IPC) and rape (S.376 IPC) are non-compoundable offences.

title: Acquittal
content: Court finding accused not guilty and releasing them from charges after trial.. Example: After full trial, court acquits accused due to lack of evidence under S.232 CrPC.

title: Conviction
content: Court finding accused guilty and imposing punishment after trial.. Example: Court convicts accused under S.304 IPC and sentences to 10 years imprisonment.

title: Cognizance
content: Magistrate taking judicial notice of offence and deciding to start proceedings.. Example: Magistrate takes cognizance of fraud case based on police chargesheet under S.190 CrPC.

title: Plea Bargaining
content: Accused pleading guilty in exchange for lesser charge/sentence with court permission.. Example: In theft case, accused pleads guilty for reduced sentence under S.265A CrPC.

title: Habeas Corpus
content: Court order to produce detained person to examine legality of detention.. Example: Family files habeas corpus petition when person missing after police detention.

title: Abetment
content: Instigating, conspiring or intentionally aiding commission of crime.. Example: Providing weapon knowing it will be used for murder amounts to abetment under S.109 IPC.

title: Attempt
content: Act done with intention to commit crime but falling short of completion.. Example: Pointing loaded gun and pulling trigger but gun jams is attempt to murder under S.307 IPC.

title: Common Intention
content: Shared plan among group to commit criminal act, making all liable for actions.. Example: Five people planning robbery together are all liable for murder if one kills guard under S.34 IPC.

title: Right to Private Defence
content: Right to use reasonable force to protect oneself or property against imminent attack.. Example: Using force to prevent burglar from entering house is private defence under S.96 IPC.

title: Documentary Evidence
content: Evidence in document form like contracts, letters, receipts presented in court.. Example: Forged cheque presented as evidence in cheating case under S.3 Evidence Act.

title: Oral Evidence
content: Verbal testimony given by witness in court under oath.. Example: Victim describing incident to judge constitutes oral evidence under S.59 Evidence Act.

title: Expert Evidence
content: Opinion evidence given by qualified expert on specialized subjects.. Example: Doctor's opinion on cause of death or handwriting expert's analysis are expert evidence under S.45 Evidence Act.

title: Dying Declaration
content: Statement made by person about cause of their death while believing death is imminent.. Example: Burn victim naming attacker before dying recorded as dying declaration under S.32(1) Evidence Act.

title: Confession
content: Accused's admission of guilt made voluntarily without any inducement or threat.. Example: Accused confessing to magistrate about theft constitutes judicial confession under S.164 CrPC.

title: Admission
content: Statement suggesting inference about fact in issue, made by party to case.. Example: Accused admitting presence at crime scene but claiming innocence is admission under S.17 Evidence Act.

title: Presumption
content: Legal inference about fact existence based on proof of other facts.. Example: Person not heard from for 7 years presumed dead under S.108 Evidence Act.

title: Public Prosecutor
content: Government lawyer who represents state and conducts prosecution in criminal cases.. Example: Public Prosecutor presents evidence against accused in murder trial under S.24 CrPC.

title: Defence Counsel
content: Lawyer who represents and defends accused person in criminal case.. Example: Defence counsel cross-examines prosecution witnesses to defend accused.

title: Amicus Curiae
content: Independent lawyer appointed by court to assist in administration of justice.. Example: Court appoints amicus curiae to represent unrepresented accused in important case.

title: FIR
content: See First Information Report. Example: nan

title: NBW
content: See Non-Bailable Warrant. Example: nan

title: IPC
content: Indian Penal Code - main criminal code defining offences and punishments. Example: nan

title: CrPC
content: Code of Criminal Procedure - procedural law for criminal investigations and trials. Example: nan

title: IEA
content: Indian Evidence Act - law governing evidence admissibility in court. Example: nan

title: Tort
content: A civil wrong that causes harm or loss, leading to legal liability for the person who commits the tortious act.. Example: A shop owner fails to clean a wet floor, a customer slips and breaks their arm - this is negligence, a type of tort.

title: Injunction
content: A court order that requires a party to do or refrain from doing a specific act.. Example: A court issues an injunction to stop a factory from releasing polluted water into a river, preventing environmental damage.

title: Decree
content: The formal expression of an adjudication which conclusively determines the rights of the parties in a civil case.. Example: In a property dispute, the court passes a decree declaring Person A the rightful owner of the land.

title: Damages
content: Monetary compensation awarded by a court to a person who has suffered loss or injury due to the wrongful act of another.. Example: A driver who causes an accident due to recklessness must pay damages to cover the victim's medical bills and car repairs.

title: Right to Equality (Article 14)
content: The constitutional guarantee that the state shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws.. Example: A government job notification that excludes applicants from a particular state would violate Article 14.

title: Right to Life and Personal Liberty (Article 21)
content: The constitutional protection of an individual's life and personal liberty against arbitrary state action.. Example: The Supreme Court has held that the right to life includes the right to live with human dignity, clean air, and privacy.

title: Mandamus
content: A writ issued by a court commanding a public official or body to perform a mandatory duty they have failed to execute.. Example: A court issues mandamus to compel a municipal corporation to provide clean drinking water to a locality, a duty it is neglecting.

title: Certiorari
content: A writ issued by a higher court to a lower court or tribunal, demanding the records of a proceeding for review, often to quash an order passed without jurisdiction.. Example: The High Court issues certiorari to quash the order of a lower court that heard a case outside its legal authority.

title: Prohibition
content: A writ issued by a higher court to prevent a lower court from proceeding in a case where it lacks jurisdiction.. Example: The High Court issues prohibition to stop a civil court from hearing a case that falls under the exclusive jurisdiction of a revenue court.

title: Quo Warranto
content: A writ issued to challenge a person's right to hold a public office, questioning by what authority they hold the position.. Example: A citizen files a quo warranto petition against an appointed municipal councillor who holds a disqualification.

title: District and Sessions Court
content: The principal court of original jurisdiction in a district, handling both civil and serious criminal cases.. Example: Sessions Court tries serious criminal cases like murder (S.302 IPC); District Court handles major civil suits.

title: High Court
content: The highest court in a state, with original, appellate, and supervisory jurisdiction over all lower courts and tribunals in the state.. Example: The Delhi High Court hears appeals against decisions of district courts in Delhi and can issue writs for enforcement of fundamental rights.

title: Supreme Court of India
content: The apex court and final interpreter of the Constitution, with original, appellate, and advisory jurisdiction.. Example: An appeal against a High Court verdict in a murder case can be taken to the Supreme Court, whose decision is final.

title: Res Judicata
content: A matter already adjudicated by a competent court cannot be pursued further by the same parties, based on the principle that a dispute once decided is final.. Example: A property title suit decided by a court cannot be filed again by the losing party on the same grounds.

title: Estoppel
content: A legal principle that prevents a person from asserting a fact or right that contradicts what they have previously stated or agreed upon by their actions.. Example: A landlord who accepts rent from a tenant knowing they breached a lease clause may be estopped from later evicting them for that same breach.

title: Vicarious Liability
content: The legal responsibility of one person for the acts or omissions of another, typically an employer for the actions of an employee done in the course of employment.. Example: A company is held vicariously liable for an accident caused by its delivery driver while making a company delivery.

title: Strict Liability
content: Legal responsibility for damages or injury, even if the person found liable was not at fault or negligent.. Example: A company storing hazardous chemicals is held strictly liable if those chemicals escape and cause damage, regardless of precautions taken.

title: Negligence
content: A tort involving failure to exercise the care that a reasonably prudent person would exercise in like circumstances, causing harm.. Example: A doctor fails to diagnose a obvious illness, causing the patient's condition to worsen; this is medical negligence.

title: Public Interest Litigation (PIL)
content: A litigation filed in a court of law for the protection of 'public interest', not merely to enforce the rights of one individual.. Example: A PIL is filed to address the problem of pollution in a city, seeking orders for the government to take action.

title: Contempt of Court
content: Any act of disobedience, disrespect, or willful disregard for the authority or dignity of a court.. Example: Shouting at a judge or refusing to comply with a court order can be punished as contempt of court.

title: Arbitration
content: A form of alternative dispute resolution where a dispute is submitted to one or more arbitrators who make a binding decision.. Example: A business contract includes an arbitration clause, so any disputes are resolved by an arbitrator instead of going to court.

title: Mediation
content: A voluntary and confidential form of alternative dispute resolution where a neutral third party helps disputing parties reach a mutually acceptable settlement.. Example: In a divorce case, a mediator helps the couple agree on child custody and property division without a bitter court battle.

title: Lok Adalat
content: A 'People's Court' where cases are settled through compromise and amicable solutions, organized by the National Legal Services Authority.. Example: A long-pending motor accident claim is settled quickly at a Lok Adalat, with the insurance company agreeing to compensate the victim.

title: Caveat
content: A formal notice or warning given to a court not to take any specified action without informing the person who gave the notice (the caveator).. Example: A person expecting a false suit to be filed against them lodges a caveat in the court, so the court must hear them before passing any order.

title: Limitation Period
content: The legally prescribed time limit within which a lawsuit must be filed. After this period expires, the right to sue is generally lost.. Example: The limitation period for filing a suit for breach of contract is three years from the date the breach occurred.

title: Specific Performance
content: A court order directing a party to fulfill their obligations under a contract, typically granted when monetary damages are inadequate.. Example: A court orders a seller to transfer the ownership of a unique antique vase to the buyer as promised in the contract, instead of just paying damages.

title: Decree Holder
content: The person in whose favour a decree has been passed.. Example: In a money suit, the person awarded the money is the decree holder.

title: Judgment Debtor
content: The person against whom a decree has been passed and who is ordered to pay the money or perform the duty.. Example: In a money suit, the person ordered to pay the money is the judgment debtor.

title: Attachment of Property
content: A legal process where a court seizes property belonging to a judgment debtor to force payment under a decree.. Example: To recover a debt, the court orders attachment of the debtor's bank account.

title: Execution Proceedings
content: The process of enforcing or giving effect to a decree or order passed by a court.. Example: A decree holder files an execution petition to auction the judgment debtor's property to recover the awarded money.

title: Interim Order
content: A temporary order issued by a court during the pendency of a case, to maintain the status quo or prevent irreparable harm.. Example: A court issues an interim injunction to stop construction on a disputed plot until the final decision.

title: Ex Parte Decree
content: A decree passed in the absence of the defendant (the opposite party).. Example: If a defendant fails to appear in court despite notice, the court may pass an ex parte decree in favour of the plaintiff.

title: Stay Order
content: A court order to temporarily suspend a judicial proceeding or the enforcement of another court order.. Example: A court grants a stay order on the demolition of a building until the main petition is decided.

title: Fiduciary Relationship
content: A relationship of trust and confidence where one party (the fiduciary) is obligated to act in the best interests of the other.. Example: The relationship between a doctor and patient, or a lawyer and client, is a fiduciary relationship.

title: Good Faith
content: Honest intention to act without deceit or fraud, even if a mistake is made.. Example: A person acting on a genuinely mistaken fact, but with honest intent, is said to be acting in good faith.

title: Malafide
content: Acting in bad faith, with intentional dishonesty or ulterior motive.. Example: A public official transferring an officer out of personal vendetta is acting malafide.

title: Natural Justice
content: Fundamental principles of fairness in legal procedure, including the right to be heard and rule against bias.. Example: A student must be given a chance to explain before being expelled from university; this is a principle of natural justice.

title: Perjury
content: The offence of wilfully giving false evidence while under oath in a judicial proceeding.. Example: A witness lies in court about seeing an event; they can be prosecuted for perjury.

title: Power of Attorney
content: A legal document authorizing one person to act on behalf of another in legal or financial matters.. Example: An elderly person gives a power of attorney to their son to manage their bank accounts and property.

title: Prima Facie Case
content: A case that appears sufficient to prove the allegations at first sight, based on the initial evidence.. Example: The prosecution establishes a prima facie case in a theft trial with CCTV footage of the accused at the scene.

title: Summons Case
content: A case relating to an offence that is not a warrant case (generally, less serious offences).. Example: Cases involving offences punishable with imprisonment of less than two years are usually summons cases under CrPC.

title: Warrant Case
content: A case relating to an offence punishable with death, imprisonment for life, or imprisonment exceeding two years.. Example: Cases for serious offences like murder, rape, and robbery are warrant cases under CrPC.

title: Bona Fide
content: Acting in good faith, with genuine and honest intention.. Example: A bona fide purchaser buys property without knowing about any prior legal claims on it.

title: Mesne Profits
content: Compensation paid for the wrongful possession of land or property, covering the profits the rightful owner lost.. Example: A person illegally occupying a house must pay mesne profits to the owner for the period of occupation.

title: Specific Relief
content: A remedy aimed at the fulfilment of a contract or enforcement of a duty, rather than merely compensating with money.. Example: A court orders specific relief by directing a builder to complete and deliver a flat as per the agreement.

title: Trespass
content: Wrongful interference with one's person, property, or rights.. Example: Entering someone's land without permission constitutes trespass to land.

title: Nuissance
content: An unlawful interference with a person's use or enjoyment of their land or property.. Example: A factory creating constant noise and smoke that affects neighbouring residents is committing a nuisance.

title: Defamation
content: The act of harming the reputation of another by making a false statement to a third party.. Example: Publishing a false news article claiming a businessman is involved in fraud is defamation.

title: Contract
content: A legally binding agreement between two or more parties that is enforceable by law.. Example: Signing a lease agreement to rent an apartment creates a contract between tenant and landlord.

title: Breach of Contract
content: The failure to perform any term of a contract without a valid legal excuse.. Example: A builder's failure to complete a project by the agreed date is a breach of contract.

title: Consideration
content: Something of value exchanged between parties to a contract; it is the price for which a promise is bought.. Example: In a sale, the money paid by the buyer is the consideration for the seller's promise to deliver the goods.

title: Free Consent
content: Agreement to a contract given without coercion, undue influence, fraud, misrepresentation, or mistake.. Example: A person signing a contract after being threatened has not given free consent, making the contract voidable.

title: Act of God
content: An event caused by natural forces beyond human control, for which no person can be held responsible.. Example: A landslide destroying a factory after unprecedented rainfall would be considered an act of God, absolving any party from liability.

title: Ad Valorem
content: A tax or duty calculated as a percentage of the value of goods or property.. Example: Stamp duty on property transactions is often ad valorem, calculated as a percentage of the property's sale value.

title: Amicus Curiae
content: A neutral advisor to the court who is not a party to the case but offers expertise or insight.. Example: In a complex environmental case, the court may appoint a scientist as amicus curiae to provide technical guidance.

title: Ante Litem Motam
content: Something done or made before a lawsuit is contemplated, often considered more reliable evidence.. Example: A doctor's medical report prepared immediately after treatment, before any legal action was considered, holds greater weight as ante litem motam evidence.

title: Autrefois Acquit
content: A plea that the accused has already been acquitted of the same offence, preventing double jeopardy.. Example: An accused cannot be tried again for murder after being acquitted by a competent court; they can plead autrefois acquit.

title: Autrefois Convict
content: A plea that the accused has already been convicted of the same offence, barring a second trial.. Example: If already convicted and punished for theft, an accused cannot be tried again for the same instance of theft.

title: Benami Transaction
content: A transaction where property is held by one person but paid for by another, typically to conceal true ownership.. Example: A government official buying property in their relative's name to hide illicit wealth is a benami transaction, illegal under the Benami Transactions Act.

title: Cy-Près Doctrine
content: A legal principle allowing a court to modify the terms of a trust or charity as closely as possible to the original intent when literal execution becomes impossible.. Example: If a charity for orphaned elephants can no longer function, courts may use cy-près to redirect funds to a general wildlife charity.

title: De Hors
content: Outside the scope of or unrelated to the matter at hand.. Example: Evidence about a person's character may be considered de hors if presented in a contract dispute with no relevance to the case.

title: Demurrer
content: A plea that even if the facts presented by the opposite party are true, they do not constitute a valid cause of action.. Example: In a defamation case, the defendant may file a demurrer stating that the published words are not defamatory in law.

title: Detinue
content: A wrongful withholding of someone's personal property after the owner has demanded its return.. Example: A borrower refusing to return a borrowed laptop after the agreed period commits detinue.

title: Ejusdem Generis
content: A rule of interpretation meaning 'of the same kind,' where general words following specific words are limited to the same category.. Example: A law prohibiting 'vehicles, cars, trucks, and other motorized conveyances' would not include bicycles under ejusdem generis.

title: Force Majeure
content: An unforeseeable circumstance that prevents someone from fulfilling a contract, often called an 'act of God' clause.. Example: A pandemic lockdown may be considered force majeure, excusing parties from contractual deadlines.

title: Garnishee Order
content: A court order directing a third party who holds money for a debtor to pay it directly to the creditor.. Example: A court may issue a garnishee order to a bank to transfer funds from the debtor's account to the decree holder.

title: Hearsay Evidence
content: Evidence not based on the witness's direct knowledge but on what others have said, generally inadmissible.. Example: A witness testifying 'my friend told me he saw the accident' is giving hearsay evidence, which is usually not allowed.

title: In Camera Proceedings
content: Court hearings conducted in private, not open to the public, often to protect privacy or sensitive information.. Example: Trials in rape cases are often held in camera to protect the victim's identity and dignity.

title: In Limine
content: A motion made at the start of a trial to decide on an evidentiary or procedural issue before the main proceedings.. Example: A party may move in limine to exclude certain prejudicial evidence from being presented to the jury.

title: In Pari Delicto
content: When both parties are equally at fault or in wrongdoing; a defense where the court may refuse to assist either party.. Example: If both parties knowingly entered an illegal contract, a court may refuse to enforce it, citing in pari delicto.

title: Ipso Facto
content: By the fact itself; something that is automatically true as a direct consequence of an action or fact.. Example: A person convicted of a felony may ipso facto be disqualified from holding certain public offices.

title: Lis Pendens
content: A pending lawsuit; a legal notice that a property is involved in litigation, warning potential buyers.. Example: A lis pendens notice is registered on a property title during a ownership dispute, preventing its sale.

title: Mandatory Injunction
content: A court order requiring a party to perform a specific act to rectify a wrong.. Example: A court may issue a mandatory injunction ordering a neighbor to demolish a wall built on someone else's land.

title: Mandamus
content: A writ issued by a higher court to a lower court, tribunal, or public authority, directing them to perform a public duty they are legally obligated to do.. Example: If a municipality fails to provide basic sanitation, a citizen can seek a writ of mandamus to compel action.

title: Negotiorum Gestio
content: A quasi-contract where a person voluntarily manages the affairs of another without their request but must act in their best interest.. Example: A neighbor repairs the roof of a house whose owner is abroad to prevent damage; this is negotiorum gestio.

title: Nemo Dat Quod Non Habet
content: A legal principle meaning 'no one can give what they do not have'; a person cannot transfer better title than they themselves possess.. Example: A thief cannot sell stolen goods and pass good title to an innocent buyer, based on nemo dat quod non habet.

title: Obiter Dictum
content: A remark or opinion by a judge that is not essential to the decision and does not establish binding precedent.. Example: A judge's comments on a hypothetical scenario not directly relevant to the case are obiter dicta.

title: Pari Passu
content: On equal footing; without preference or priority.. Example: In bankruptcy, unsecured creditors are often paid pari passu, meaning proportionally from the available assets.

title: Quantum Meruit
content: A claim for reasonable payment for services rendered when no formal contract exists or the contract is void.. Example: A builder hired without a fixed price can sue on quantum meruit for the reasonable value of work done.

title: Quasi-Judicial
content: The power of an administrative body to make rulings and decisions that resemble those of a court.. Example: The Consumer Forum exercises quasi-judicial powers when it hears complaints and awards compensation.

title: Qui Facit Per Alium Facit Per Se
content: A legal maxim meaning 'he who acts through another acts himself'; the principle of vicarious liability.. Example: An employer is responsible for the actions of their employees performed within the scope of employment.

title: Res Integra
content: A point of law without precedent or previous judicial decision; a new question for the court.. Example: A case involving liability for damage caused by a drone may be res integra, as there is no existing law on it.

title: Res Nullius
content: Something that belongs to no one; ownerless property that can be acquired by the first person who takes possession.. Example: Wild animals are generally considered res nullius and can be appropriated by capture.

title: Sub Judice
content: A matter that is currently under consideration or pending in a court, prohibiting public discussion to avoid prejudice.. Example: The media should avoid detailed reporting on a sub judice case to not influence the proceedings.

title: Subpoena
content: A court order requiring a person to appear in court to testify as a witness.. Example: A doctor may be served a subpoena to appear in court and present their medical findings in a personal injury case.

title: Subrogation
content: The right of an insurer who has paid a claim to take over the insured's rights to recover the loss from a third party.. Example: An insurance company that pays for car repairs after an accident can sue the at-fault driver through subrogation.

title: Suo Motu
content: When a court takes action on its own motion, without a formal request from a party.. Example: The Supreme Court took suo motu cognizance of the migrant crisis during the lockdown to address the situation.

title: Tortfeasor
content: A person who commits a tort, a civil wrong that causes harm or loss to another.. Example: A driver who causes an accident by running a red light is a tortfeasor and liable for negligence.

title: Ultra Vires
content: An act beyond the legal power or authority of a person or institution.. Example: A municipal corporation passing a tax law beyond the powers granted to it by statute acts ultra vires.

title: Volenti Non Fit Injuria
content: A defense meaning 'to a willing person, no injury is done'; one cannot claim for harm they voluntarily consented to.. Example: A boxer injured in a match may not sue for battery, as they consented to the risk by participating.

title: Writ
content: A formal written order issued by a court commanding the performance of a specific act.. Example: The five major writs for enforcing fundamental rights are Habeas Corpus, Mandamus, Prohibition, Certiorari, and Quo Warranto.

title: Ab Initio
content: From the beginning; something that is void ab initio is treated as invalid from the outset.. Example: A contract signed under coercion is void ab initio and has no legal effect from the start.

title: Amicus Curiae
content: See above. Example: nan

title: Bona Vacantia
content: Ownerless goods or property that, by law, revert to the government.. Example: The assets of a dissolved company with no heirs may be claimed by the government as bona vacantia.

title: Corpus Delicti
content: The body of facts that prove a crime has been committed, often literally the body in a murder case.. Example: In a murder trial, the prosecution must establish the corpus delicti, i.e., that a person died and that death was caused by a criminal act.

title: De Novo
content: Anew; a trial de novo is a completely new trial, as if the first one never happened.. Example: An appellate court may order a trial de novo in a lower court if there was a major procedural error.

title: Estoppel
content: See above. Example: nan

title: Ex Gratia
content: A payment made as a favor, without admission of any legal liability or obligation.. Example: A company may make an ex gratia payment to the family of a deceased employee, even if not legally required to do so.

title: Funus Officii
content: The completion or termination of an official's duties, often upon death or resignation.. Example: The funus officii of a public servant occurs upon their retirement, ending their official authority.

title: In Situ
content: In its original place; left undisturbed.. Example: Archaeological artifacts are sometimes studied and preserved in situ rather than being moved to a museum.

title: Jus Tertii
content: A right of a third party; a defense where a defendant claims that the property belongs to someone else, not the plaintiff.. Example: A tenant in a possession suit may raise a jus tertii defense, claiming the true owner is a third party, not the landlord bringing the suit.

title: Locus Standi
content: The right to bring a legal action or to be heard in court, based on a sufficient connection to the issue.. Example: A citizen must demonstrate locus standi, or sufficient interest, to file a Public Interest Litigation (PIL).

title: Modus Operandi
content: A particular method of operation, especially characteristic of a criminal.. Example: The police linked the robberies to the same suspect based on a distinctive modus operandi, like disabling alarms in a specific way.

title: Noscitur a Sociis
content: A rule of interpretation meaning 'it is known by its associates'; a word is understood by the words surrounding it.. Example: In a list 'dogs, cats, and other animals,' the phrase 'other animals' would be interpreted in the context of domestic pets (noscitur a sociis).

title: Onus Probandi
content: The burden of proof.. Example: In a criminal case, the onus probandi lies on the prosecution to prove guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.

title: Per Incuriam
content: A judgment passed 'through lack of care,' ignoring a relevant statute or binding precedent, making it not authoritative.. Example: A High Court judgment that overlooks a Supreme Court ruling on the same point is per incuriam and not binding.

title: Pro Bono
content: Legal work undertaken voluntarily and without payment, for the public good.. Example: A lawyer may represent an indigent client pro bono publico, meaning for the public good without a fee.

title: Pro Tanto
content: To that extent; partially.. Example: A payment made pro tanto reduces the debt or claim to that extent but does not fully settle it.

title: Quantum
content: The amount or extent of something, especially the amount of damages to be awarded.. Example: The court must determine the quantum of compensation required to adequately cover the victim's medical expenses and lost income.

title: Ratio Decidendi
content: The essential legal principle or reasoning behind a court's decision, which forms a binding precedent.. Example: The ratio decidendi of a landmark case is the core rule that lower courts must follow in similar future cases.

title: Sine Die
content: Indefinitely; adjournment of a court case without setting a future date.. Example: The hearing was adjourned sine die due to the absence of a key witness, with no new date announced.

title: Stare Decisis
content: The legal principle of following precedents set by previous court decisions.. Example: Under stare decisis, a lower court is bound to follow the legal principles established by higher courts in prior cases.

title: Sub Silentio
content: Something passed over in silence; a point of law that was not explicitly considered or ruled upon in a decision.. Example: A previous case might have been decided sub silentio on a key issue, meaning that issue wasn't addressed and thus doesn't set a precedent.

title: Suo Motu
content: See above. Example: nan

title: Uberrimae Fidei
content: Of the utmost good faith; contracts requiring full disclosure of all material facts by the parties.. Example: An insurance contract is uberrimae fidei, so the applicant must disclose all relevant health information truthfully.

title: Voir Dire
content: A preliminary examination of a witness or juror to determine their competence or suitability.. Example: During voir dire, lawyers question potential jurors to check for any biases that might affect the trial.

title: Can a woman get free legal aid?
content: Yes, all women are entitled to free legal aid regardless of income.

title: Can you help me with: 32. Can an application for grant of legal services be made by a person on behalf of another based on a general power of attorney??
content: Generally no. The application for legal aid has to be made in person generally and not through an authorized representative (except in cases of children or person with mental illness). The legal aid application has to be accompanied by the Affidavit sworn by the person seeking grant of legal aid (when a person is claiming free legal aid based on annual income criteria) and such an Affidavit cannot be made on behalf of some other person. However, in some cases, if the person seeking legal aid is incapacitated for some reason to apply in person for legal aid, his duly authorized representative/ person holding his General Power of Attorney may apply for legal aid.

title: 8. How is free legal aid different from legal advice and assistance?
content: Legal aid is the provision of legal representation to a person in the District Courts, High Courts and Supreme Court or tribunals, by a lawyer assigned by the Legal Service Authority concerned.Legal Advice and Assistance is the provision of advice on general areas of law as governed by the laws of India by the lawyers employed with the Legal Services Institution concerned. For e.g. if a person has to file a case in court, he would be provided legal aid (in form of assignment of a Legal Services Advocate). However, if he only needs some help in drafting a legal notice to be sent prior to filing of a complaint under Section 138 of the Negotiable Instruments Act 1881, he would get legal consultation/ advice regarding the same. A person who does not come under the purview of Section 12 of Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, to be eligible for free legal aid, can still avail legal advice and assistance from the Legal Services Institutions.

title: Are senior citizens eligible for legal aid?
content: Yes, senior citizens are entitled to free legal aid under Section 12 of the Act.

title: What is the process for filing a charge sheet?
content: The police prepare a charge sheet after completing the investigation and submit it to the court.

title: What are the steps involved in 72.	how can one file an application before the permanent lok adalats for public utility services??
content: An application can be filed before the Permanent Lok Adalats for Public Utility Services on a plain paper depicting the true and correct facts and the details of the person/Authority/public utility services provider against whom relief is claimed, on any working day. Such an application should however, be accompanied by supporting documents and copies to be furnished to the opposite party.

title: Help me know about: 31. If a person has an annual income which is more than the amount prescribed under the Legal Services Authorities Act/ extant rules in this regard in the different states, can he still get free legal aid if he falls within any other category of beneficiaries enlisted in Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act?
content: Yes. If he falls within any other category mentioned in Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. For e.g. a man from the Scheduled Tribe, even if he is earning Rs. 10 lakhs per annum, is eligible for free legal aid.

title: What is the procedure for: 67.	what is a permanent lok adalat??
content: It is an inexpensive forum for amicable resolution of a dispute between an aggrieved person and a Public Utility Service provider.

title: Please explain: 18. Till what age is a child eligible for free legal aid?
content: A child is eligible for free legal aid till the age of majority i.e. 18 years. This is provided in Section 12 (c) of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. So, any child can apply for free legal aid till he turns 18 years old. Even on attaining the age of majority, the child can continue to get free legal aid, if she/ he falls within the other criteria enlisted in Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987.

title: Can you help me with: 20. Can a child being prosecuted for a criminal offence be provided free legal aid??
content: A child alleged to be in conflict with law is entitled to free legal aid.

title: Can you help me with: 36. Can a wealthy businessman who is in custody in a case of cheating be given free legal aid??
content: A person who is facing criminal trial and is in police/ judicial custody is entitled to get free legal aid irrespective of his financial status or social standing. There is no bar under Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987 to provide Free Legal Aid to a wealthy businessman if he happens to be a prisoner.

title: Help me know about: 43.	Who is a Legal Aid Defence Counsel?
content: Legal Aid Defence Counsels are appointed by the District Legal Services Authority to provide legal representation in criminal matters within the district. They are attached to the Legal Aid Defence Counsel office and are dedicated only to provide legal aid services i.e. they cannot take up any private legal cases. They are neither Government pleaders or advocates nor public servants.

Those persons who have annual income of less than the amount prescribed by the respective State Government, if the case is before any court other than the Supreme Court, and less than Rs. 5 Lakhs, if the case is before the Supreme Court, are eligible for free legal aid. title: Please explain: 60.	When can legal aid be denied or withdrawn?
content: Legal Aid can be denied at the initial stage before the application for legal aid is accepted. It can also be withdrawn at the later stage after the application has been accepted and legal aid has been provided. Legal aid can be denied or withdrawn in the following circumstances:Legal aid can be denied if a person is found ineligible under Section 12 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987;Legal aid can be withdrawn if the aided person who applied under the income category is found to possess sufficient means;Legal aid can be withdrawn where the aided person obtained legal services by misrepresentation or fraud;Legal aid can be withdrawn where the aided person does not cooperate with the Legal Services Institution or with the Legal Services Advocate;Legal aid can be withdrawn where the person engages a legal practitioner other than the one assigned by the Legal Services Institution;Legal aid can be withdrawn in the event of death of the aided person except in the case of civil proceedings where the right or liability survives;Legal aid can be withdrawn where the application for legal service or the matter in question is found to be an abuse of the process of law or of legal services.Regulation 6 of the National Legal Services Authority (Free And Competent Legal Services) Regulations, 2010 provides that the applicant shall be informed that if free legal services have been obtained by furnishing incorrect or false information or in a fraudulent manner, the legal services shall be stopped forthwith and that the expenses incurred by the Legal Services Institutions shall be recoverable from him or her.

title: Can you help me with: 44.	Who are para-legal volunteers??
content: Paralegal volunteers (PLVs) are volunteers selected from diverse social and educational backgrounds through the process of NALSA’s Para-Legal Volunteers Scheme. They are expected to act as intermediaries in bridging the gap between the common people and the Legal Services Institutions reaching out to the people at their doorsteps.

title: What should I do for: 70.	what type of disputes in public utility services the permanent lok adalats for public utility services would decide??
content: The Permanent Lok Adalats for Public Utility Services would decide disputes relating to deficiency in service, claims for damages/ compensation, recovery of money, etc., pertaining to all Public Utility services.

title: Help me know about: 85.	What role does NALSA and other Legal Services Institutions play in promoting legal aid awareness in schools and colleges?
content: They organize programs in educational institutions to enhance legal awareness among students, ensuring a foundation of legal knowledge from an early age. It conducts awareness programs such as legal literacy workshops and seminars in schools and colleges. It engages students in interactive sessions using Acts and presentations. It also distributes informative brochures and pamphlets about child rights. Various legal service clinics are also established in schools and colleges.

title: What is the procedure for: 4. what are the district legal services authorities and the taluka legal services committees? what are their roles and responsibilities??
content: Section 9 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, provides for the constitution of the District Legal Services Authorities (DLSAs) by the State Government, in consultation with the Chief Justice of the High Court, for every District in the State, to exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred on, or assigned to, the DLSA under Sections 10 and 11 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. The DLSA is headed by the District & Sessions Judge of the respective district as the Chairman, DLSA.Similarly, Section 11A of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, provides for the constitution of the Taluka Legal Services Committees (TLSC) by the State Authority for each Taluka or mandal or for a group of Talukas or mandals, to exercise the powers and perform the functions conferred on, or assigned to them, under Section 11B of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987. The TLSC is headed by the senior Civil Judge operating within its jurisdiction as the ex-officio Chairman.As per Sections 10 and 11 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, it shall be the duty of every DLSA to perform such of the functions of the State Authority in the District as may be delegated to it from time to time by the State Authority. The DLSA may perform all or any of the following functions, namely:Coordinate the activities of the TLSC and other legal services in the District;Organize Lok Adalats within the District;Perform such other functions as the State Authority may fix by regulations.The DLSAs are expected to act in coordination with other agencies and be subject to directions given by the NALSA, for promoting the cause of legal services to the poor.As per Section 11B of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, it shall be the duty of every TLSC to:Co-ordinate the activities of legal services in the Taluka;Organize Lok Adalats within the Taluka; andPerform such other functions as the DLSA may assign to it.

title: What is the procedure for: 82.	what is mediation??
content: Mediation is a non-binding negotiation process in which a neutral third person facilitates the parties to the dispute in arriving at a mutually acceptable settlement. The process is informal where the outcome of the dispute is controlled by the parties themselves. The entire process is confidential. Civil cases, matrimonial and family disputes are best suited for mediation.

title: I want to understand 12. how can one approach nalsa/ slsa/ dlsa/ tlsc/ hclsc/ sclsc? where can an application for legal aid be made?

title: What are the steps involved in 8. how is free legal aid different from legal advice and assistance??

For e.g. if a person has to file a case in court, he would be provided legal aid (in form of assignment of a Legal Services Advocate). title: 2. What is the role and function of NALSA?
content: As per Section 4 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, NALSA has been assigned to perform all or any of the following functions:Laying down policies and principles for making legal services available under the provisions of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987;Framing the most effective and economical schemes for the purpose of making legal services available under the provisions of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987;Utilizing the funds at its disposal and making appropriate allocations of funds to the State Authorities and District Authorities;Taking necessary steps by way of social justice litigation with regard to consumer protection, environmental protection, or any other matter of special concern to the weaker sections of the society and for this purpose, give training to social workers in legal skills;Organizing legal aid camps, especially in rural areas, slums, or labor colonies with the dual purpose of educating the weaker sections of the society as to their rights as well as encouraging the settlement of disputes through Lok Adalats;Encouraging the settlement of disputes by way of negotiation, arbitration, and conciliation;Undertaking and promoting research in the field of legal services with special reference to the need for such services among the poor;Doing all things necessary for the purpose of ensuring commitment to the Fundamental Duties of citizens under Part IVA of the Constitution;Monitoring and evaluating implementation of the legal aid programmes at periodic intervals and providing independent evaluation of programmes and schemes implemented in whole or in part by funds provided under this Act;Providing grants-in-aid for specific schemes to various voluntary social service institutions and the State and District Authorities, from out of the amounts placed at its disposal for the implementation of the legal services schemes under the provisions of this Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987;Developing, in consultation with the Bar Council of India, programmes for clinical legal education and promoting guidance and supervising the establishment and working of legal services clinics in universities, law colleges, and other institutions;Taking appropriate measures for spreading legal literacy and legal awareness amongst the people and, in particular, to educate weaker sections of the society about the rights, benefits, and privileges guaranteed by social welfare legislations and other enactments as well as administrative programmes and measures;Making special efforts to enlist the support of voluntary social welfare institutions working at the grassroots level, particularly among the Scheduled Castes and the Scheduled Tribes, women, and rural and urban labor; andCoordinating and monitoring the functioning of State Authorities, District Authorities, Supreme Court Legal Services Committee, High Court Legal Services Committees, Taluka Legal Services Committees and voluntary social service institutions and other legal services organizations and give general directions for the proper implementation of the legal services programs.As per Section 5 of the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987, NALSA has also been entrusted with the duty to work in coordination with other agencies for the purposes of providing access to justice to the marginalized sections of the society.

title: How do I go about 60.	when can legal aid be denied or withdrawn??

title: I want to understand 3. what are the state legal services authorities? what are their roles and responsibilities?
